Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This CCLI Type 2 project involves the creation, adaptation, and dissemination of new learning materials and teaching strategies that have the potential to transform undergraduate education in mathematics and computer science. Math Images II develops a model for providing undergraduates who might consider a STEM major with pre-research experiences working with and learning to write math, and extends this model to also include computer science and preservice education students. Students engage face-to-face and online as participants in supervised summer research groups or they are involved in special projects during an academic year course. As part of the plan to scale and extend the CCLI Phase I Math Images project that engaged undergraduate students in writing and understanding mathematics, this project includes a diverse group of student participants from a wide variety of institutions and disciplinary preparations who collaborate in the development of content managed online through the Math Forum. Participating students learn to write mathematics to explain the content of images, to construct images or software programs to help understand the mathematics of the images, or to develop course materials that include work with image pages. They are supported through collaborations with faculty, peers, and online resource personnel (mathematicians, computer scientists, math education faculty, and teachers) to revise their work so it can be published on the Math Images wiki (beta version, http://mathforum.org/mathimages/).

This project develops teaching strategies and new learning materials to transform the quality of STEM education for undergraduates. It brings together students from different disciplinary backgrounds, faculty, and online resource personnel as collaborators and models for how to think and work with images and mathematics. The development of a rubric for assessing open-ended mathematics writing and study of participant work with instructional conversation should enable this experience to be scaled in relation to participants' entering strengths and needs and, in turn, improve the quality of their participation.

This project makes four types of contributions. First, it contributes a resource that can provide the general public with enriched understanding of what mathematics actually is while serving as both an instructional resource for classroom work at all levels, and a new vehicle for student projects. Second, it documents the motivation and learning of student participants involved in working with images and mathematics writing, programming, and/or lesson design that takes advantage of and contributes to web resources. Third, the project yields a rubric for assessing open-ended mathematics writing that is tested and refined through its application to the work of a diverse pool of participants. This is a resource that is needed for both mathematics classrooms and studies of learning from new media. Finally, the project documents the forms of feedback that support learners who differ in motivation and prior experience with mathematics. Little information is currently available about how to respond to the strengths and needs of learners with different motivational and learning profiles. Findings are disseminated to both research and practitioner audiences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The long-range goals of this CCLI Type 2 project, Math Images II, were two-fold. First, the project was designed to contribute to undergraduate education in STEM, at the same time fine-tuning the potential of pre-research experiences that include collaborative, inquiry-oriented, project-based learning and that enable participating students to explore and develop their abilities to think and communicate with others about mathematics. A second long-range goal was the continued development of a dynamic site, Math Images, designed to reposition the general public’s conceptions of mathematics as a science of patterns, not just formulas and numbers, and provide a gateway to further interest in mathematics. (Note: Gene Klotz, of the Math Forum, was the lead PI on this project throughout its duration. Jason Silverman was appointed custodial PI by Drexel University at the end when the Math Forum was being transitioned to the National Council of Teachers of Mathematics (NCTM). Final reports and studies were prepared by Ann Renninger, project evaluator, Swarthmore College, and Stephen Weimar, Director, The Math Forum, NCTM.)

Math Images II, extends a model that supported undergraduates who were considering a STEM major following either the first or second year of college with pre-research experiences that developed their abilities and interest in working with and learning to write math. Workshops included diverse groups of student participants collaborating with faculty, peers, and online resource personnel (mathematicians, computer scientists, math education faculty, and teachers) as they engaged in research and worked to revise their work for publication on the Math Images wiki (http://mathforum.org/mathimages/).

Use-inspired evaluation studies provided formative feedback to project partners. The studies provide a description of student experiences and learning about mathematics and writing mathematics from the workshop context, in addition to design principles for writing mathematics that is assessable to the general public. Studies addressed: (1) the development and use of a tool for assessing open-ended mathematics writing, (2) the experience and learning of participating undergraduates, (3) students’ work with Math Image pages that for them varied in their level of difficulty, and (4) the roles of text [esoteric, public] and learner characteristics (prior course work in mathematics, proof scheme [empirical, analytical], gender, interest in mathematics) in undergraduate students’ identification of metamathematical concepts (e.g. definitions, theorems, proofs) and comprehension of argument (e.g. data, warrant, claim).

Intellectual Merit: This project responded to the CCLI call to use and develop teaching strategies and new learning materials to transform the quality of STEM education for undergraduates. It brought together students from different disciplinary backgrounds, faculty, and online resource personnel as collaborators and models for how to think and work with images and mathematics. Project findings should enable this type of pre-research experience to be scaled in relation to participants’ entering strengths and needs and, in turn, impact the quality of their participation in mathematics. The findings also have implications for the design of learning environments that can successfully respond to differences among learners.
